awd_titl_txt: New Strategy for Synthesis of Atomically Precise Graphene Nanoribbons
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry.  Professor Guangbin Dong of the University of Chicago is supported to develop new approaches for the synthesis of single carbon atom thick graphene nanoribbons arranged in precise armchair pattern.  Each ribbon is a tiny fraction of a human hair in width.  These materials have potential applications as semiconductors in light-weight and flexible electronic devices.  This project addresses the challenges of preparing ribbons with various chemical functional groups and band structures to be incorporated in a new generation of molecular devices.  While conducting the project, the Dong group is actively participating in the Leadership Alliance Summer Research Early Identification Program.  The intention is to integrate the project with education and outreach and to encourage diverse undergraduate students to explore careers in science and engineering. 
   
The project aims to offer an efficient approach to prepare armchair graphene nanoribbons (aGNRs) with controlled electron band structures and high charge mobility.  The project advance three main objectives: to enable a unified approach to prepare aGNRs with various widths; to synthesize aGNRs with precisely installed functional edges; and to develop a chain-growth-polymerization approach to access aGNRs with controlled lengths and prepare aGNR-based P/N junctions.  The project makes available a wide range of aGNRs, designed to test and validate hypotheses and theoretical models proposed previously by physicists and physical chemists.  The results are expected to accelerate the physical and theoretical studies of these intriguing materials and to advance the understanding of these graphene-like one-dimensional polymers, which in turn would further inspire and stimulate the development of other new conjugated organic semiconducting materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
[Intellectual Merit]:

Graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) have emerged as attractive organic materials for potential application in high-speed, light-weight and flexible electronic devices, due to their non-zero bandgaps and high theoretical charge carrier mobility. However, efficient, and practical synthesis of more soluble and processable GNRs remains an unsolved issue. The goal of this proposal is to develop novel and practical approaches for preparation of atomically precise armchair GNRs that could be ultimately used in high performance electronic devices. In the funding period, we have developed a simple modular approach to prepare various GNRs with different widths and edge functions based on "triaryl" monomers. In addition, a uniquely patterned piperazine-based sidechain has been identified to address the aggregation and solubility issue of conjugate aromatic polymers, which opens the door for preparing water-soluble GNRs. Moreover, a mild, cobalt-catalyzed cyclodehydrogenation method under photochemical conditions has been realized, which holds great promise for preparing GNRs with diverse functional groups. Five research articles based on the works achieved in this period have been published in top chemistry journals, including one in Nature Communications and one in Angewandte Chemie.

 

[Broader Impacts]: First, this project has provided important training to graduate students, Ki-Young Yoon and Tatsuhiro Tsukamoto. They got valuable experience in organic synthesis and material characterization. Ki-Young found a postdoc position at Caltech, and Tatsuhiro secured a postdoc position at Harvard. Second, eight undergraduate students were mentored during this period to participate in research, and three of them have already earned a publication. In addition, three undergraduate students have been admitted to top graduate schools, including Stanford, Purdue, and Tokyo Universities. Moreover, the PI has actively participated in the Leadership Alliance program and Collegiate Scholars program, assisted the recruitment of undergraduate and high-school students with diverse backgrounds. Finally, the PI has successfully recruited an African American first-year graduate student to his research lab, who is currently working on GNR synthesis. It is expected that these outreach activities would greatly encourage diverse and minority students to explore careers in science and engineering while learning and actively contributing to material research.


Last Modified: 09/16/2021
Modified by: Guangbin Dong
